papers.title: Accurate frequencies of molecular transitions used in laser stabilization: the 3.39-μm transition in CH4 and the 9.33- and 10.18-μm transitions in CO2
papers.abstract: <jats:p>The frequencies of three lasers stabilized to molecular absorptions were measured with an infrared-frequency synthesis chain extending upwards from the cesium frequency standard. The measured values are 29.442 483 315 (25) THz for the 10.18-μm R(30) transition in CO2, 32.134 266 891 (24) THz for the 9.33-μm R(10) transition in CO2, and 88.376 181 627 (50) THz for the 3.39-μm P(7) transition in CH4. The frequency of methane, when multiplied by the measured wavelength reported in the following letter, yields 299 792 456.2(1.1) m/sec for the speed of light.</jats:p>

llm_analysis.reasoning: This paper explicitly mentions 'CH4' and 'accurate frequencies of molecular transitions'. This strongly suggests the presence of experimentally measured, high-precision transition frequencies with likely quantum number assignments and uncertainties, which are ideal inputs for the MARVEL algorithm.

papers.title: Tunable cw Pb0.98 Cd0.02S diode lasers emitting at 3.5 μm: Applications to ultrahigh-resolution spectroscopy
papers.abstract: <jats:p>Continuously tunable cw diode lasers that produce narrow-line (1- to 10-MHz linewidth) radiation in the 3.5-μm region have been fabricated from Pb0.98Cd0.02S. Lasers operating at 10–20 K produced more than 1 mW of cw power distributed among several modes which could be tuned continuously &gt; 1 cm−1 by adjusting the laser current. A spectral range of 30 cm−1 could be covered over the full operating range. Ultrahigh-resolution (10−5 cm−1) spectra of H2CO have been obtained to demonstrate the potential application of these lasers to the identification of organic molecules by spectroscopy of their C–H stretch absorption bands.</jats:p>

llm_analysis.reasoning: This paper describes a laser source for 'ultrahigh-resolution spectroscopy'. The specified emission wavelength (3.5 μm) is highly relevant as it falls within the strong C-H stretch fundamental band of methane. While it's a methods paper, such a system is designed to produce the precise, high-resolution experimental transitions with uncertainties that are crucial inputs for the MARVEL algorithm for molecules like methane.
